body_html:
Yes; that will work. You will have to create two SparseTensors: one taking
the real values and one taking the imaginary values (the indices and shape
tensors can be the same).

On Fri, Oct 21, 2016 at 4:21 PM, QED notifications@github.com wrote:

Is there a quick fix to this without using ScatterNd? For instance, if the
sparse tensor is complex, one could split into real and imaginary parts
(not sure if this is available for a sparse tensor) and then call
sparse_tensor_to_dense?

—
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.

body:
Yes; that will work.  You will have to create two SparseTensors: one taking
the real values and one taking the imaginary values (the indices and shape
tensors can be the same).

On Fri, Oct 21, 2016 at 4:21 PM, QED notifications@github.com wrote:

> Is there a quick fix to this without using ScatterNd? For instance, if the
> sparse tensor is complex, one could split into real and imaginary parts
> (not sure if this is available for a sparse tensor) and then call
> sparse_tensor_to_dense?
